Fans cheer for actor, disrupt CM Vijayan.description: PALAKKAD: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan cut short his inaugural address at the opening of a hospital here on Sunday, following the clamour by a bunch of Mohanlal fans. The chief minister and the actor shared the dais during the inauguration of Avitis Institute of Medical Sciences at Nemmara here. The fans started cheering the actor as soon as he entered along with the CM. The uproar continued even as the CM started addressing the gathering. A visibly irked Vijayan said, “Those who are cheering the actor lives in their own world. They do not know any other things. This may be because they are immature. But they are not doing a service to the actor either.” Before concluding his speech, the chief minister said, “Considering the progress the state has achieved, it does not have enough specialized medical facilities. We (the government) have been requesting the central government to sanction an All India Institute of Medical Science (AIIMS) for long, to meet the increasing demands in Kerala.” He added that he had met Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi on Saturday and urged him to accord the sanction for AIIMS in Kerala. “The Central government is expected to consider Kerala’s demand,” the CM said. He also added that the opening of Avitis Institute of Medical Sciences with super specialty departments in cardiology, neurology, nephrology, gastroenteritis, renal science etc, was a big step forward in the health sector in the state. The function was presided over by assembly speaker P Sreeramakrishnan. Health minister K.K. Shailaja, agriculture minister V S Sunil Kumar, water resources minister K Krishnankutty, MLA s O Rajagopal and K Babu, MPs V K Sreekantan and Remya Haridas, UAE Exchange founder chairman B R Shetty among others were present. Unifying school education: HC stays stat.description: KOCHI: The Kerala high court on Monday issued a stay on state government's decision to merge three directorates of school education into one. A stay was issued by the court after considering petitions challenging implementation of the report of a three-member committee headed by MA Khader that recommended for a unified directorate of education at the school level and creation of the post of director general of education by unifying the three directorates – directorate of public instruction, higher secondary directorate, and vocational higher secondary directorate. It was alleged by the petitioners that the government's move would give the charge of principal of higher secondary school to headmaster of high school. As headmasters need not have post graduation and higher secondary school teachers need post graduation, it would result in placing a head master over higher secondary school teachers. Nair Service Society (NSS), which runs many schools in the state, had also questioned implementation of the commission report before the high court. It was alleged by NSS that the orders issued by the government are contrary to Kerala Education Act and its rules as well as provisions of Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act (RTE) and its rules. The government’s move also hinders the time-tested public education system that has separate administrative setup as well as teaching and non-teaching staff with qualifications befitting the physical and mental growth of children, NSS had contended. Signs of Presence art exhibition throws.description: An exhibition titled Signs of Presence being showcased at the Durbar Hall Art Centre, in Kochi, brings together the artworks of three artists such as Akhil Vijayakumar, Ayyappa Das IR and Vishnu CS. The group exhibition brings together mediums such as paintings, sculptures and graphic prints. Be it anything in life, there is a process of action and reaction, and how even presence or absence of something can convey meanings of their own. The exhibition captures the curious responses of these artists to various situations. Idukki church officials remove wooden cr.description: IDUKKI: The wooden crosses, which were erected atop the hills of Panchalimedu tourism point, were removed by church officials on Tuesday. Earlier, Hindu Aikyavedi had filed a complaint before Idukki district collector H Dineshan alleging that authorities of Kanayankavayal St Mary’s Church were trying to encroach upon the revenue land. They also erected a trident (trishul) atop the hill to protest the move. Following this, the collector had directed the church authorities to remove the wooden crosses. Peruvanthanam village officer R Wilson said, “Three wooden crosses were installed by the church authorities on last Good Friday. The church would erect crosses before Good Friday and would remove them. But this year, the church authorities failed to remove the crosses.”  The trident was also removed. Three generations of alumni come togethe.description: Clad in a saffron sari adorned with rudraksha ornaments, the member of the erstwhile Travancore royal family, Pooyam Tirunal Gouri Parvathi Bayi represented a sage on stage. She was one of the 87 performers at the alumni event organised by the Old Students Association (OSA) of the Government Women’s College, Thiruvananthapuram. Titled Vasthrayana, the dance drama themed on the evolution of garments in India was a visual treat for those in attendance at the Karthika Tirunal Auditorium, recently. The cultural extravaganza saw performances of three generations of students, from the previous pre-degree batches to the recent graduates. Hundreds of alumni including homemakers, working professionals, artistes and bureaucrats, joined the performers at the venue to take a stroll down memory lane to relive their campus life. While those who had become great grandmothers enjoyed watching the show, many were looking around for their old batchmates. Though time had changed their physical appearance, many still found their pals, by calling out their nicknames. Singer Kanchana Sreeram, BA Music graduate of the 2017 batch, portrayed a South Indian bride on the show and says the event gave her friendship goals. “At a time when video calls and group chats are the norm, this alumni group stands apart because the reunion is held regularly without fail. I am happy I could see our super seniors and their seniors still joke around like in their younger days. I think they were the most enthusiast bunch at the event,” she says. “I was also surprised to see the performance of Princess Gouri Parvathi Bhayi, who danced flawlessly.” The dance drama narrated the evolution of garments with time — from the stone age to contemporary dressing styles. The event was held under the guidance of Pooyam Tirunal Gouri Parvathi Bayi, who is the OSA secretary. “The show is held every two years. The 87 members who were part of this show were of different ages and from all walks of life. We had grandmothers and mothers alongside granddaughters and daughters. It was hard work but fun too. Our dance director Aswathy Nair worked tirelessly to ensure seamless production and Ambili Ramnath’s expertise with words and Kavalam Sreekumar’s magic with the music have always been the mainstay of our performances,” she says. Apart from performing, for Gouri Parvathi Bayi, it is also an event to meet her friends and teachers. “I have never really left the Women’s College - as a student, teacher and as part of the Alumni association, I have always remained in touch with the institution. For most of us, there is a sense of homecoming when we step into the college compound. The years fall away, and we feel rejuvenated. Ultimately in life, our real earnings are the friendships we have forged, the wonderful experiences nobody can take away from us and precious memories that stay with us always. Many of our older members make it a point to come to our meetings and events. They make a greater physical effort than youngsters who work a full day and have homes to run too,” she adds. Actress Sona Nair was also part of the event, enthralling her friends in her avatar as goddess Saraswati. “This is an event that I eagerly look forward to. I feel blessed meeting my old teachers and classmates, and giving me memories to cherish for the next two years. Each of the 87 artistes were given a three-and-half-minute performance and so that ensured everyone had equal time to perform,” she says, adding that she always makes it a point to find time amid her shooting schedules to make it to the reunion. Dept stops winter vegetable zone project.description: Idukki: The agricultural department has finally stopped the much expected Devikulam winter vegetable zone at Vattavada in Munnar without fulfilling its purported aim. In 2017, agricultural minister V S Sunilkumar has announced a winter vegetable zone in Vattavada and Kanthalloor, including Devikulam block, to make the region as the winter vegetable hub of the state. Sunilkumar had inaugurated over Rs 11 crore worth winter vegetable and fruit production development project in Kanthalloor and Vattavada and promised that the government will boost winter vegetable and fruit production in the area and will develop the centre as the state’s best vegetable production centre. But after the three years, the project has stopped without any benefit to the farmers in the region. A department official said the government might announce another project that is why it is stopping the zone. Vattavada winter vegetable farmers’ society president K Jayaprakash said, “The farmers in the Kanthalloor and Vattavada regions expected that the winter vegetable zone project will be completed soon. The farmers in the region have not been getting any benefit from the winter vegetable zone project for the last three years.” “The Vattavada and Kanthalloor regions have a huge potential to produce winter vegetables and fruits. The subsidy announced for winter vegetable farmers in the region has not been distributed yet,” Jayaprakash said. Prince Mathew, Idukki agricultural deputy director (Horticulture mission), said: “The three year project has completed its tenure, and winter vegetable production has increased in the area. The subsidy money of the farmers will be distributed soon.” Vattavada and Kanthalloor regions are known as the hub of cool season vegetables. An estimate of 2,725 hectares of winter vegetables were cultivated in the region. Potato, beans, cabbage, carrot and garlic are the main cool season vegetables in Kanthalloor and Vattavada, natives said. “The agricultural minister will visit Vattavada and Kanthalloor .We expect the minister will announce a big project in Kanthalloor and Vattavada to encourage the winter vegetable production,” an agricultural department official said. BJP Candidate List.description: NEW DELHI: Amid rumblings over ticket denials in some seats like Kanpur, where saffron veteran   Murli Manohar Joshi has been benched   , and Bangalore South, where the wife of late party leader Ananth Kumar was overlooked for a young debutant, BJP issued on Tuesday a list of 43 nominees for the Lok Sabha polls. Not budging in the face of Joshi’s stiff resistance to being asked to step aside, BJP announced Satyadev Pachauri, a minister in the UP cabinet, as the replacement for the octogenarian leader. The list of 30 candidates for UP, however, accommodated women and child welfare minister Maneka Gandhi and her son Varun Gandhi, who were allowed to swap their Pilibhit and Sultanpur seats. Other interesting picks include   actor-politician Jaya Prada   , who was named against SP leader Azam Khan from Rampur in UP soon after she joined BJP. The selection ignites an old and bitter rivalry, as the former Bollywood star is close to former SP leader Amar Singh who has scores to settle with SP and Khan. Another UP cabinet minister, Rita Bahuguna Joshi, a former UP Congress chief who joined BJP, will contest from the prestigious constituency of Allahabad, where the sitting party MP, Shyama Charab Gupta, has left for SP and is contesting from Banda. She is the daughter of the late H N Bahuguna, a former UP chief minister and well-known Congress leader. Law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad, the party’s candidate from Patna Sahib, faced protests when he landed in Patna on Tuesday. The protesters claimed loyalty to BJP’s Rajya Sabha MP R K Sinha, who was later pulled up by the party while sources said the heckling was led by a person identified as an expelled BJP member. Varun Gandhi, who has had his ups and downs in BJP, was on the list of nominees and will stake his claim for Pilibhit, which has been a family bastion. Maneka Gandhi will be pitted in a triangular contest against SP-BSP alliance candidate Chandrabhanu Singh, alias Sonu Singh, a local politician with clout among Rajput voters who could have turned up the heat for Varun. Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh is in the fray as the Congress nominee. Joshi, a former BJP president, made no secret of his displeasure at being denied a ticket and went public by releasing a letter addressed to voters of Kanpur saying he received a call from party general secretary (organisation) Ramlal asking him not to contest the polls. Joshi, 85, has been asked not to contest just as it was decided that 91-year-old party patriarch L K Advani will not fight from Gandhinagar. Joshi’s defiant note was possibly the reason behind the nomination of a Brahmin face as another UP state minister, Satish Mahana, had been talked of as the frontrunner to replace the veteran leader The party decision is in line with several veterans not being nominated to pave way for younger leaders. The 2019 election will see the curtain drop on the electoral politics of what was seen the Vajpayee-Advani era in the party. BJP has also not given tickets to B C Khanduri, Karia Munda, Kalraj Mishra, Bijoya Chakravarty — all MPs for several terms and over 80 years of age. BJP sprang a surprise by giving 28-year-old Tejaswi Surya, an advocate and Karnataka Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha general secretary, the ticket from Bangalore South, belying expectations that Tejaswini Ananth Kumar would be its choice for the constituency her husband represented six times. The choice triggered strong protests and even state BJP president B S Yeddyurappa said they had sent only Tejaswini’s name, which, he claimed, was changed in Delhi. Tejaswini had to issue statements to mollify her supporters as she said the polls were about re-electing Narendra Modi as Prime Minister. BJP has announced 349 candidates, including 62 in UP, so far. Two seats in UP have been left for alliance partner Apna Dal (Sonelal). Party president Amit Shah will decide the remaining 16 seats in UP where sitting MPs are likely to be replaced, and a reason behind delaying the announcement is to reduce prospects of dissidence and rebellion. The party has so far dropped 14 sitting MPs in UP. BJP general secretary Arun Singh announced that Union minister Manoj Sinha has been fielded from Ghazipur, a seat he had won in 2014. BJP’s Kisan Morcha chief Birendra Singh Mast has been shifted from his sitting seat Bhadohi to far-east Ballia in UP, replacing sitting MP Bharat Singh, whose poor performance was a concern for the party. Agra MP Ram Shankar Katheria, head of the SC commission who had been denied renomination from the current seat, has been moved to Etawah (SC), replacing Ashok Kumar Dohray. UP BJP president Mahendra Nath Pandey has been repeated from Chandauli. In Video:No Murli Manohar Joshi in BJP list of 43Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Degree Show\u201919 gets a new space.description: The artwork of the students of the College of Fine Arts Thiruvananthapuram no longer need to just vie for space in their classroom. They now get to exhibit them at the new spacious art gallery building inside their college premises. The occasion was their Degree Show ’19 and on display were the prominent art and installation works of students of the recent batches from the college. Communicating various subjects and ideas, the art pieces was a visual treat. The week-long show which kicked off on June 14 also included talks by eminent personalities from the field of art. We saw film critic C S Venkiteswaran talking to young artists on contemporary art. A soothing break was necessary, says cir.description: Kochi: Circle inspector V S Navas, who went incommunicado on Thursday after an argument with a senior officer and returned on Saturday after 44 hours, told reporters that he would act according to the department’s directions. On Friday, Navas’s wife had said that her husband went incommunicado after facing harassment from a senior officer. However, Navas is yet to say anything against his superiors in public on his return. He said that a break was necessary for peace of mind. “When we have troubles, we either cry or will approach someone for comfort or we seek solitude. I wanted some solitude so that I can get relaxed. I have been living mechanically for long. Our soul needs some food, like travel, talking with friends, meeting our Guru, reading good books, listening to music, etc. Some others resort to alcohol or drugs, which I can’t,” Navas told reporters on Sunday.  Navas had gone incommunicado after an argument with ACP P S Suresh. He was transferred to Mattancherry before he went incommunicado, however, sources said that the posting would happen only after the DCP completes the probe and submits a report to the higher ups. “The probe will be conducted by analysing documents and records. We will maintain a status-quo regarding the CI’s posting. He will be meeting the IG on Monday. Senior officers, including the DGP, will take a call on his posting. The newly-appointed CI will take charge at Ernakulam Central while temporary arrangements will be made at Mattancherry,” said a senior officer. Meanwhile, experts said that both officers are likely to face disciplinary action. Officers said that even if there was pressure within the force, officers should be able to withstand them. “Now, the officer concerned is most likely to get a memo for unauthorized absence. What he should have done was to report to his senior, if another officer had used unparliamentary language over the wireless. There would be a recording of it and there would be an action for sure,” said Rtd SP George Joseph. However, officers close to Navas said that he was not someone who bows to pressure. “I know him for years. He has struggled so much over the years. If he wanted to run away, he would have done it much earlier. This means that pressure on him would have been so intense that he would have reached a breaking point,” said an officer. Beto Ruiz to helm a production based on.description: Teachers, artists, aspiring actors, anchors and school-kids got together on Saturday at Riverbourne Centre, Tripunithura, to spend a day with theatre director and trainer Beto Ruiz from Mexico. As the day progressed, most of them, to whom the acting class was a novelty, were fully engrossed in Beto’s engaging conversations and ‘games’. The tips and tricks he shared in the class, according to the participants, were not just lessons in acting, but for life.  “I was super-excited to attend the training ever since I read about him. It was truly worth it. I loved the way he communicated ideas and how he explained to us the importance of knowing one’s own body. Being a college lecturer, it is really important to know how to build a connect with my students and how to transform myself by transforming others,” says Lesly Augustine, assistant professor, Sacred Hearts College, Kochi.  Beto Ruiz Beto, who heads the acting department at the Intercultural Theatre Institute (ITI) in Singapore, has found his third home at Kerala. He, together with a few artistes and art enthusiasts, including koodiyattom performer Kapila Venu, has started a collective in Kerala named Across the River to create international productions. The collective aims at bringing together actors from across the world, including from ITI. “We are creating and devising a new project which is inspired by the works of Arundhati Roy’s God of Small Things and Perumal Murugan’s One Part Woman respectively. We are rehearsing at Irinjalakuda,” says Beto, adding that as an outsider he can view India through new eyes, though he has learnt koodiyattom, kalaripayattu and other art forms of Kerala. “I am focusing more on inter-culturalism with an exchange of ideas, cultures and views with others and seeking people’s responses to the current times. The two books surprised me as I was able to resonate with Mexican social issues while reading it. So, I understood, there is a connection between the two countries; we are not similar, yet we are not totally different.” Talking about the recent workshop, Beto says that he was excited to see that there are so many people at the workshop interested in performing and who aspire to be artistes. “The exchange I have with experienced actors who attend my workshop is fulfilling. The more I do, the more questions I have, be it from books or the conversations. They make the dialogues fresh and make my life productive and healthy. When freshers walk in, I see less ego, less vanity and more energy. An artiste is at first a human and then an artiste, so it will be always good for anybody to be part of acting classes. I see people who get so inspired for life from the games we play. My aim is to create honest performers,” he says. An expert in Kundalini Yoga, Beto picked theatre as a career when he was 15. After completing an undergraduate course in theatre at Guadalajara, Mexico, Beto went to Singapore as he felt there was a need to preserve the holistic approach traditional theatre brings in, where dancers, singers, musicians and actors work together. So, he studied Asian theatre forms and did a theatre training and research programme in Singapore. His prominent works as a director include operas, such as Verdi’s La Traviata and Purcell’s Dido and Aeneas, and plays such as Dario Fo’s Un Dia Cualquiera and Alfred Jarry’s King Ubu. He has also worked on productions in the US, Colombia and Poland. “I was completely trained in realism, as three decades ago, that was the only practice in Mexico. I felt attracted with the mysteries of our body, so I was also trained in contemporary dancing. Then I began doing physical theatre and dance theatre and started exploring its possibilities. At ITI, I found Michel Chekov’s style interesting and that is what I am now working on. I am also following the idea of interdisciplinary practice, using the body in all its possibilities,” he says, adding that the Across the River collective’s project will feature all these ideas. Removal of name from voters\u2019 list w.description: Kochi: It is illegal to remove a voter from the voters list without giving him an opportunity of hearing, the high court has said. Inaction by the voter in getting his name restored also won’t justify such action, the court said. The judgment by Justice Shaji P Chaly came after considering a petition filed by 64-year-old A Subair of Chala in Thiruvananthapuram, questioning the removal of his name from the voters’ list prepared for the Lok Sabha elections this year. Names of his wife and daughter were retained while his was removed on the report of booth level officer that he changed his residence. Referring to Section 22 of the Representation of the People Act of 1950, the court pointed out that the statute says the voter should be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. The judgment said, “On an evaluation of the said provisions, it is explicit that, they are peremptory in nature and can never be brushed aside or overlooked. Proviso thereto makes it clear that before removing a person from the voters list, the electoral registration officer is duty bound to give the person concerned a reasonable opportunity of being heard in respect of the action proposed to be taken. Which thus also means, the action or enquiry contemplated under Sec 22 of the Act, 1950 is not an empty formality, but on the other hand, founded on principles of natural justice, which if violated, action becomes arbitrary and illegal inviting action against the officer concerned.” No opportunity of hearing was given to the petitioner in the case, the court added. The Election Commission had contended that the removal from voters’ list was preceded by several steps such as inviting objections to draft electoral roll, including giving publicity to ‘deleted lists’ and that a final electoral roll was published at the end of a process that lasted over a year. After finding that no opportunity of hearing was granted to the petitioner, the court said, “It is also apposite to mention that, mere inaction on the part of the petitioner to restore the name removed from the voters list, is not a justification for removing the name, otherwise than in accordance with law.” The court then ordered the chief election commissioner of Kerala to conduct a detailed inquiry into the incident and, if required, take appropriate action against the officers who removed the petitioner’s name from the voters list within two weeks. Vagamon gets a Rs 99lakh worth facelift.description: Idukki: In a bid to attract more tourists to Vagamon, the tourism department has completed infrastructure works estimated at Rs 99 lakh in the hill station. The works gave a facelift to the destination, said Idukki District Tourism Promotion Council secretary (DTPC) Jayan P Vijayan. The works covered entrance gate, tourism information centre, ticket counter, lifted stone-laid walkway with flowering plants on either side, benches, toilets, rest rooms, censors, LED lightings and waste bins. “The construction works were entrusted with central government agency Vapcos. A garden close to the lake and a children park will be constructed in Vagamon in the second phase of the tourism project,” Jayan said. “The new facilities will be inaugurated during the monsoon tourist season. As many as five lakh tourists visited Vagamon in last year. Nearly 1.5 lakh tourists reached Vagamon during the monsoon last year. The heavy tourist inflow shows Vagamon have a vast tourism potential,” Vijayan said. Para gliding, pine plantation, evergreen meadows are the main attractions in Vagamon. It is a favourite to the tourists for its vast view of the hills from the open space and chilly weather in any season. Vagamon is considered as the third main tourism destination in Idukki. “We hope the new infrastructure works will attract more tourists to the destination. The wide parking area form part of the new infrastructure will be the additional attraction in the destination,” Jayan said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Binoy Kodiyeri is my child\u2019s father.description: MUMBAI: A 33-year-old woman here, who has filed rape and cheating charges against CPM Kerala state secretary Kodiyeri Balakrishnan’s son, on Tuesday said that she had incontrovertible proof to show that Binoy Kodiyeri was the father of her child and that she herself was willing to undertake a DNA test to prove it. The woman had got an FIR registered against Binoy Kodiyeri at the Oshiwara police station here on June 13. The birth certificate and passport of the woman’s eight-year-old son show Binoy Vinodini Balakrishnan alias Binoy Balakrishnan Kodiyeri as his father. The woman has already submitted several documents to the Oshiwara police as evidence of her close relationship with the CPM leader’s son. The documents include her bank statements between 2010 and 2015, which showed Binoy Kodiyeri had electronically transferred Rs 80,000 to Rs 1 lakh every month to her as maintenance. Sources close to the woman said that her recent letter to Binoy, which the latter claimed was an attempt to blackmail, had merely sought more money from him for the boy’s upbringing. “The woman’s letter for Rs 5 crore was sent in consultation with her lawyer and it clearly says the money is to take care of their child,” a police officer confirmed. Sources told TOI that Oshiwara police were expecting Binoy Kodiyeri to cooperate with the investigation. “There are photos of the woman with Binoy Kodiyeri and their child, and even family photographs to prove that there was no problem between the two till 2015. Problem started after 2015 when Binoy Kodiyeri refused to give money to the woman and even stopped visiting her house,” a police officer told TOI. Mumbai police spokesperson Manjunath Singe said the Oshiwara police were collecting evidence before taking action and that he was unaware if any lookout notice was being issued for Binoy Kodiyeri. Green Card.description: NEW DELHI: In an attempt to strike a balance between those standing in queue for decades for employment-based green cards (owing to the per country caps) and the need to protect American workers, a bill - 'The Fairness for High Skilled Immigrants Act (S.386)', has been recently amended by Republican Senator Mike Lee. The amendments are being seen as a bid to facilitate its passage. To provide more protection to American workers, it requires that the employer sponsoring H-1B workers must disclose online (for at least 30 days) various details of the job on offer, such as occupation or job position, education and experience requirements, location and also how to apply for this job. A filing fee is also sought to be introduced forLabour Condition Applications(LCA), which is an attestation-based requirement that has to be met by sponsoring employers prior to filing of H-1B visa applications. This bill was originally introduced in the US Senate on February 7. It sought to remove the per country cap on employment-based green cards and shorten the wait time for the vast majority of applications in the backlog. US issues 1.40 lakh employment-based green cards annually. Substantial increase in denial of H-1B petitions of Indians: ReportHowever, not more than 7% can go to nationals of any one country. With a high influx of the Indian diaspora in the US, it has resulted in a heavy backlog, with those in the EB-2 category (having advanced degrees) having to face a wait time of 151 years. "Over the last decade, various bills to remove this per country cap, have failed to become law. S. 386 has been rescued from the fate of its predecessors through appeasement, specifically, by agreeing to amendments that would allow further restrictions on merit-based non-immigrant visas, particularly with regards to the H-1B programme. However, it is interesting to note that many of these so-called 'new' restrictions already exist in one form or another," Florida based immigration attorney, Ashwin Sharma, told TOI. For instance, even currently,   H-1B sponsoring employers have to certify   that they are not favouring immigrant workers over American workers. They have to indicate how they calculated the prevailing wages they are offering to H-1B workers (but these records are to be made available only on specific request of the concerned authorities), explained Sharma. While the bill would alleviate the green card backlog and significantly benefit India, followed by China, it also seeks to ensure that the green card for others is not delayed beyond the time it would have otherwise taken, had this bill not been passed. Another similar bill HR 1044, introduced by the Democrats is pending in the US House. 'Immigration Voice', a US based non-profit which is engaged in alleviating problems faced by legal highly-skilled immigrants, in its social media post on June 17, said that it has reached a deal with Senator Lee and the amendments will enable the bill to pass. "We have a deal to break the deadlock in the Senate!," it posted on Twitter. A note, issued by it analysing the various facets of S.386 including the amendments, states that the bill allows investigations against H-1B frauds to be based on anonymous complaints, eliminates arbitrary deadlines on investigations and permits investigations for general non-compliance with LCA requirements, as opposed to simply for a wilful violation. It seeks to increase the penalties for LCA violations that have remained unchanged since 1990. Whistle-blower protection, which is already available, is also incorporated in the amendment. The fee proposed for LCA documentation will be used to fund the department of labour's (DOL's) administrative and investigative activities associated with H-1B programme. A few amendments in the bill, such as the 30 day internet posting requirement, could cause delays and challenges, states an immigration expert. Another counsel says: "Companies can depute their employees on a B-1 (business) visa to the US for a temporary period. The requirement was that the salary should be borne by the non-US employer. While a B-1 was getting tougher to obtain, it was an option available. The bill seeks to eliminate the 'B-1 in lieu of H-1B' option. We need to see how this will pan out." Teacher gives birth four months after ma.description: MALAPPURAM: A pre-primary teacher of a government UP school in Kottakkal has approached police alleging that the school authorities and the parent-teacher association of the school did not allow her to rejoin duty after maternity leave as she gave birth to a child after just four months of marriage. She has also accused parents and teachers of verbally abusing her at a PTA meeting. Kottakkal police will record the statement of the 33-year-old teacher on Wednesday. According to the complaint filed by the woman, she has been working at the school for the past five years. She has been divorced for some time but was preparing for a second marriage. As the divorce procedures of the first marriage were getting delayed, she had started to live with her second husband even before legally marrying him. Later, they got legally married in June 2018 and she applied for maternity leave four months after the marriage. She delivered a baby on the second day after she applied for the leave. In her complaint, the woman said when she came to the school after her leave ended in January 2019, the school authorities did not allow her to rejoin pointing out that she had applied for maternity leave just four months into her marriage. The woman approached child rights commission seeking action against the school authorities. Subsequently, the commission sought a clarification from the deputy director of education (DDE). After a few months, when the summer vacation ended, the DDE completed its inquiry and issued a directive to the school authorities to allow the woman to rejoin service. But the headmaster and PTA officebearers were not ready to follow the DDE’s directions. “We approached the school authorities citing the direction from the DDE. They convened a meeting, in which they verbally insulted me, besides refusing to allow me to rejoin. I filed a police complaint on June 14. The school authorities don’t have the right to discuss my personal life at a PTA meeting. I don’t know why they are bothered about my marital life and my pregnancy period,” said the teacher. “We have started an investigation against the school authorities based on the complaint and a case would be registered after recording the woman’s statement,” said sub-inspector of Kottakkal police station Sandhya Devi. Unifying school education: Kerala HC sta.description: KOCHI: The Kerala high court on Monday issued a stay on state government’s decision to merge three directorates of school education into one. Justice PV Asha issued a stay for two months after considering during admission hearing a petition (WP-C No. 15937/2019) filed by higher secondary school teacher Saju Mathew of Kadanad in Kottayam and two others. In addition to this petition, Nair Service Society (NSS) and Aided Higher Secondary School Teachers Association have also approached the court. It was alleged in the petition that implementation of the report of the three-member committee headed by MA Khader to unify the three directorates – directorate of public instruction, higher secondary directorate, and vocational higher secondary directorate – goes against the provisions of Kerala Education Rules (KER). The government has issued an order whereby the principal of higher secondary wing has been entrusted with the charge of high school wing. The two wings are separate units and it is not intended in the statute, the petition said. It is pointed out by the petitioners that a higher secondary school teacher (HSST) requires a post graduation whereas a headmaster of a school need not have post graduation. On re-designating the headmaster as principal, he would be intermediate of HSST and principal. Thus, a lesser-qualified person is placed above the HSST, which is against fairness. When a headmaster is re-designated as vice principal, it would create a stalemate in granting promotion to HSST as principal over and above the vice principal. Such a system would create havoc in the realm of school administration, the petition said. In its petition, NSS has alleged that the government’s move goes against Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act (RTE), in addition to Kerala Education Act and KER. The three-member committee went beyond its terms of reference and its recommendation for a monolithic administrative structure goes against RTE’s idea of stand-alone primary and upper primary section with separate administrative setup, NSS has argued. The committee’s recommendation also goes against the principle of decentralization and has proceeded without conducting any empirical study, NSS’ plea had stated. Meanwhile, state government has filed an affidavit stating that it implemented the policy decisions after wide consultations with all stakeholders in the best interest of the public and the student community in general. A principal would hold the charge of all academic and administrative matters of higher secondary section whereas a vice principal will hold the charge of high school section, government said in the affidavit. Its decision to implement the unification in stages is intended to provide a uniform governance structure in all administrative and other matters in a campus having higher secondary school, high school, and vocational higher secondary school, government said, adding that there would be no change in service conditions, monetary benefits, or opportunities of employees. Postal ballot fraud: HC grants time to E.description: KOCHI: The Kerala high court on Tuesday granted three more weeks to Election Commission to hand over records related to postal ballot fraud to crime branch. A division bench comprising chief justice Hrishikesh Roy and justice AK Jayasankaran Nambiar granted time as the election commission informed that more time is required to sort the votes polled by policemen on duty outside their home district during the Lok Sabha election. The court is considering a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala seeking a probe by an independent commission. In a statement filed in the court, the election commission had stated that three forms (12, 13B, 13C) related to postal ballot can be inspected by the investigation officer whereas form 13A, which contains the declaration by electors and attestation of their signatures should not be opened or their contents should not be inspected by or produced before any person or authority except under the order of a competent court. Urgent instructions are being issued to district election officers or returning officers to furnish the three forms to the investigating officer and to cooperate with the probe so as to facilitate the investigation to reach its logical conclusion at the earliest, the statement filed by election commission’s counsel Murali Purushothaman said. It is alleged in the PIL that over 55,000 proxy votes were polled by representatives of Left-aligned Kerala Police Association by misusing postal votes of police officials who were on duty outside their home districts on the election day. The court has scheduled a hearing in the case after three weeks. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Kerala state lottery Sthree Sakthi SS-16.description: NEW DELHI: The Kerala lottery department will announce the results of Sthree Sakthi SS-162 lottery on Tuesday. The results will be available on Kerala lottery department's official website. The live results will be out at 3pm while the full results will be available from 4pm onwards. The first prize is of Rs 60 lakh, the second prize is of Rs 50 lakh while the third is of Rs 5,000. There is a consolation prize of Rs 8,000. The lottery draw will be conducted by Kerala lottery department at Sree Chithra Home Auditorium. The price of a single lottery ticket is Rs 30. The prize winners are advised to verify the winning numbers with the Kerala lottery results, published in the Kerala Government Gazette, and surrender the winning tickets within 30 days. Lok Sabha Poll 2019.description: LUCKNOW: With electioneering for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls gaining steam in Uttar Pradesh, political leaders are increasingly resorting to personal attacks on their adversaries. If the maverick BJP MLA from Bairia, Surendra Singh hit the headlines for his remarks against BSP supremo Mayawati, Uttar Pradesh cabinet minister Shrikant Sharma hit a new low by making indecent comments on Congress chief Rahul Gandhi. The Bairia MLA had said Mayawati gets facials done and her hair coloured even though she is 60-years-old. He also reportedly made offensive remarks against UPA chairperson Sonia Gandhi and Haryanvi singer-dancer Sapna Chaudhary, evoking widespread criticism from political parties and social media users. A media agency quoted him as saying that both Sonia Gandhi and Sapna Chaudhary used to work as dancers. "Rahul's mother (Sonia Gandhi) was also in the same profession in Italy and his father made her his own. He (Rahul Gandhi) should also take the family tradition forward and make Sapna his own," the MLA said. The BJP legislator, who is known for his controversial statements, had earlier termed Rahul Gandhi and his sister Priyanka Gandhi Vadra "Ravana and Shurpanakha", and accused Mayawati of "murdering" a woman's dignity by joining hands with one-time arch rival Samajwadi Party. UP Power Minister Shrikant Sharma stirred up a hornet's nest with his tweet terming the Congress president a "coward and impotent". The comments triggered a war of words between the two parties as well as on social media platform. Firebrand Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath also finds mention in the list of leaders accused of making personal remarks against political rivals. He recently termed Congress candidate from Saharanpur, Imran Masood, the son-in-law of Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Azhar Masood. Addressing a rally in Saharanpur on Sunday, Adityanath said, "The son-in-law of Azhar Masood has entered the constituency and he speaks the language of the terror mastermind. "You people have to ensure that the person who speaks the language of Azhar Masood is defeated in the Lok Sabha elections," he said while seeking votes for BJP candidate from Saharanpur, Raghav Lakhanpal. Union minister and BJP MP Mahesh Sharma referred to Rahul Gandhi as 'Pappu' and his sister Priyanka Gandhi as 'Pappu ki Pappi' during a poll campaign in Gautam Buddh Nagar. Rahul Gandhi has often been mocked by the BJP and his opposition as 'Pappu', a colloquial sneer. "Pappu kehta hai main prime minister banunga Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu.. aur ab 'Pappu ki Pappi' bhi aa gayi hai. Wo Priyanka kya pehle hamare desh ki beti nahi thi kya, Congress ki beti nahi thi kya, aage nahi rahegi kya? kya naya leke aayi hai?" the minister told a crowd of his supporters on March 16. The quotes loosely translate to "Pappu says he wants to become prime minister. Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu ... and now 'Pappu's Pappi' has also arrived. Wasn't Priyanka already a daughter of this nation, a daughter of the Congress? And would she not remain so in future? What new has she brought in?" Lost votes: Removal from voters list wit.description: KOCHI: It is illegal to remove a voter from the voters list without giving him an opportunity of hearing, says the Kerala high court. Inaction by the voter in getting his name restored also won’t justify such action, the court said. The judgment by justice Shaji P Chaly was after considering a petition (WP-C No. 13684/2019) filed by 64-year-old A Subair of Chala in Thiruvananthapuram questioning removal of his name from the voters list prepared for the Lok Sabha Elections this year. Names of his wife and daughter were retained while his was removed on the report of booth level officer that he changed his residence. Referring to section 22 of Representation of the People Act of 1950, the court pointed out that the statute says the voter should be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. The judgment said, “On an evaluation of the said provisions, it is explicit that, they are peremptory in nature and can never be brushed aside or overlooked. Proviso thereto makes it clear that before removing a person from the voters list, the electoral registration officer is duty bound to give the person concerned a reasonable opportunity of being heard in respect of the action proposed to be taken. Which thus also means, the action or enquiry contemplated under Sec.22 of the Act, 1950 is not an empty formality, but on the other hand, founded on principles of natural justice, which if violated, action becomes arbitrary and illegal inviting action against the officer concerned.” No opportunity of hearing was given to the petitioner in the case, the court added. The Election Commission had contended that the removal from voters list was preceded by several steps such as inviting objections to draft electoral roll, including giving publicity to ‘Deleted Lists’ and that a final electoral roll was published at the end of a process that lasted over a year. After finding that no opportunity of hearing was granted to the petitioner, the court said, “It is also apposite to mention that, mere inaction on the part of the petitioner to restore the name removed from the voters list, is not a justification for removing the name, otherwise than in accordance with law.” The court then ordered the chief election commissioner of Kerala to conduct a detailed enquiry into the incident and, if required, take appropriate action against the officers who removed the petitioner’s name from the voters list within two weeks. Jaya Prada.description: HYDERABAD: It’s been a roller coaster ride for actress Jaya Prada in politics. The actress, who started off as a Telugu film heroine dominating the scene along with Sridevi some decades ago, changed her political course on Tuesday by joining the BJP. In the last 25 years of her political career, she has changed several parties. Hailing from Rajahmundry in Andhra Pradesh, she began her political career with the Telugu Desam Party in 1994 as she had done several films alongside TDP founderpresident N T Rama Rao. After N Chandrababu Naidu took over as chief minister, he nominated her to the Rajya Sabha and she served a term from 1996-2002. While in the TDP, Jaya Prada had a running feud with Renuka Chowdhary who was also in the TDP then. When it became clear that she was being ignored in the TDP, Jaya Prada looked for greener pastures elsewhere. The Samajwadi Party led by Mulayam Singh Yadav in Uttar Pradesh got Jaya Prada into its party fold. She contested the Rampur Lok Sabha seat from that state on the SP ticket and won in 2004. In the 2009 elections, she got re-elected from the same constituency. With differences sprouting between SP leader Amar Singh and Mulayam Singh Yadav, Jaya prada had to make a choice on who she would sail with. She preferred to join the new party that Amar Singh floated but that proved to be a futile exercise. Jaya Prada then joined the Rashtriya Janata Dal, led by Ajit Singh in UP, making the move along with Amar Singh. In the 2014 elections she was fielded as an LS candidate from Bijnor but lost. For some time, there was speculation that Jaya Prada would return to the Telugu Desam Party when she met Andhra Pradesh chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu in Amaravati in November 2015. It turned out that she had met Naidu only to invite him for her son Siddharth’s wedding that month in Hyderabad. In 2013, Jaya Prada had met Congress president Sonia Gandhi and that also led to speculation that she would join the Congress. She had even announced that she was interested in getting back to her home state and would continue her political career there. She was keen on returning to AP politics but nothing concrete materialised. On Tuesday, she was welcomed into the BJP at the party’s headquarters in Delhi. “I am working with a brave leader in whose hands India is safe,” she said about Modi. BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. \nActor Farhaan Faasil sports a stylish.description: While his brother and actor Fahadh Faasil handles a variety of looks with ease, Farhaan Faasil is mostly spotted in his carefree yet cool signature style.  However, at a recent literary event in Kochi, the actor sported a never-seen-much-before whisker and what's more, he carried it off with elan! Farhaan, who has just completed his romcom 'Basheerinte Premalekhanam,' had the company of many renowned directors of Mollywood including his dad Fazil, Siby Malayil, Kamal, Joshiy and Lal Jose. Nagpur BJP Candidate List.description: NAGPUR: After deadline for withdrawal for the first phase of Lok Sabha polls, 31 out of 147 candidates, whose nomination papers were found valid in seven constituencies of Vidarbha, have withdrew their papers. Now, 116 candidates are in the election fray, according chief electoral officer. Those remaining in the fray across seven constituencies are — Wardha – 14, Ramtek – 16, Nagpur – 30, Bhandara-Gondia – 14, Chandrapur – 13, Yavatmal-Washim – 24 and Gadchiroli-Chimur – 5. BJP leaders in Bhandara-Gondia are heaving a sigh of relief as two of the four rebels, Khushal Bopche and Prakash Malgave, have withdrawn from the fray after hours of persuasion by them. However, Rajendra Patle is still in the fray. Virendra Jaiswal, who resigned from BJP before nominations, is not being considered rebel as he contests every time. BJP’s Sunil Mendhe is pitted against Nana Panchbudhe of NCP here. Bopche’s rebellion had created panic in the BJP camp as he is popular in the Pawar community and in general among OBCs. In Nagpur, Abdul Karim Patel and Ravikant Meshram, withdrew on Thursday, taking the total number to three. Pallavi Nandeshwar had withdrawn on Wednesday. In Ramtek, Sachin Shende, Gajanan Jambhulkar, Prakash Tembhurne, Ranjit Saphelkar and Lalit Shamkuwar have opted out of the race. In Yavatmal-Washim and Wardha, seven and two candidates respectively withdrew on the final day. One independent candidate withdrew his nomination in Gadchiroli-Chimur constituency on Thursday. (With inputs from TO Abraham & Balwant Dhage) Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23. Court stays Jose\u2019s elevation as cha.description: IDUKKI: Thodupuzha munsiff court has stayed the election of Jose K Mani as the chairman of the Kerala Congress (Mani) on Monday. The court refrained Jose from officiating the duty of the party chairman and holding the elections in the party, said the counsel of KC (M) state committee members Philip Stephen and Manohar Naduvilethu who petitioned against Jose. The order is not out yet. Jose was elected in a state committee meet held in Kottayam on Sunday. Meanwhile, Jose arrived at the party headquarters in Kottayam by evening. The name board of K M Mani outside the room of the chairman was removed and a new board with Jose 's name was fixed. Jose spent some time in the chairman's room. Before leaving he told reporters that he did not receive a copy of the order. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

No nepotism involved in appointment of m.description: KOCHI: State government has contended before the Kerala high court that there was no nepotism involved in the appointment of higher education minister KT Jaleel’s cousin KT Adeeb to a senior post in a state-run corporation. The government was responding to a petition (WP-C No. 10262/2019) filed by PK Firos of Kozhikode seeking a probe against the minister under provisions of Prevention of Corruption Act. Adeeb was appointed as general manager at Kerala State Minority Development Finance Corporation Ltd. A statement filed by minorities welfare department through state attorney KV Sohan said, “There is no corruption, favouritism, nepotism or illegality in the matter of appointment of Sri. Adeeb KT. There is absolutely no undue advantage obtained by the minister or anybody else before or after the appointment in issue.” Notification for the job opening was published in Chandrika, Madhyamam, and Deshabhimani dailies on August 27, 2016. Though another applicant, Saheer Kaladi, was invited for the interview on October 26, 2016, he did not attend the interview. While the qualification prescribed was MBA in marketing or finance or CS/CA/ICWAI with 3 years experience, MBA (HR) and BTech with PGDBA was also included on August 25, 2016. As Adeeb had the required qualification, he was appointed following recommendation to the government by the company’s board on September 11, 2018. An NOC was obtained from assistant general manager of South Indian Bank, where Adeeb was working. Adeeb later requested to be relieved and the corporation’s board requested the government to relieve him on November 13, 2018 and it was accepted on November 16, government said in the statement. The row over the appointment had surfaced early in November 2018. Government also informed the court that there was nothing wrong in Adeeb requesting annual incentive bonus and other allowances. Only an unsigned complaint was submitted before Vigilance and Anti-Corruption Bureau by email on November 3rd and the government concluded that there is no necessity of conducting an enquiry. \nBhama's attire at Lalu Alex's son's we.description: Lalu Alex’s son Ben Alex’s wedding pictures at a register office had flooded the internet recently.  Now the couple had an official ceremony which took place at the Holy Kings Knanaya Church at Piravom recently. Ben and Meenu Cyril had a traditional church wedding, according to Knanaya customs. Quite a few from the film industry dropped in to wish the couple, and actress Bhama turned up in a green full length gown. But there was more to it, as the event was organised for a noble cause, by the TV actors association, Athma. Among the audience were people affected by paraplegia. Actors Dileep, KPAC Lalitha, Manoj K Jayan and Krishna Prabha, all decked up in Kerala attire, danced and sang with the patients to give them a one -of- a -kind experience. Kerala forest officials detained by Andh.description: KOCHI: A team of seven forest officials from Idukki, who has been conducting a raid in Bomma Samudram in Andhra Pradesh's (AP) Chittoor forest division in connection with a sandal smuggling case on Monday, has been detained by AP forest officials citing that they have not taken any permission from the AP forest department. The team was detained while their way back from the raid at an private, but abandoned, sandalwood factory in Bomma Samudram. Around 728kg of sandalwood pieces, which the Kerala team seized from the sandalwood factory, are also now under AP officials' custody. The detained officers include, divisional forest officers of Munnar, Marayur and Range Officer of Marayur. Munnar DFO Narendrababu, Marayoor DFO B Ranjit and Marayoor range officer Job J Nariamparampil. According to sources, the officials have been set free after confirming their identities, but the seized sandalwood will continue to be in custody of Chittoor DFO (Andhra Pradesh) until the Kerala team gets legal clearance. The team is currently at Chittoor Forest Divisional Office pursuing talks with the DFO to release the seized sandalwood. Meanwhile, Marayur Range Officer Job J Neriamparambil told TOI that they have taken all requisite permission from the Andhra Pradesh government but did not seek AP Forest’s help to keep the secrecy of the operation. “They said that the raid was conducted within Andhra State and hence the seized property belongs to Andhra government. Though they detained us initially, we were released after confirming our identities and ministerial level intervention,” he said. It was on Sunday night the team reached Chittoor based on the information collected from Shohaib (34) alias Kunjappa, who was arrested by the team from Malappuram in connection with sandal smuggling. He had reportedly smuggled more than 10,000kg of sandal from Kerala to Andhra Pradesh. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\nSpotted Kavya Madhavan at the celebrat.description: Kavya Madhavan dazzled in a black sari at the function held in Trivandrum to mark the completion of 50 years in cinema for Malayalam filmmaker Adoor Gopalakrishnan. At the event the 75-year-old master craftsman was felicitated by his friends from all walks of life. The event was an informal gathering where actress Kavya and Kavya Madhavan shared their experiences working with Adoor. Actors like Madhupal, Manoj K Jayan, Nandu and Manju Pillai were some of the celebs who joined the celebrations, organised by Federation of the Film Societies of India’s Kerala chapter. This NH stretch turns death trap for two.description: TRIPUNITHURA: The pothole-filled road linking Pettah and Gandhi Square has witnessed two accident deaths in the past two weeks. The busy stretch of road, which experiences heavy traffic during peak hours, has turned into a death trap for two-wheeler riders. The latest victim was Santhosh, a postmaster. Santhosh fell in front of a speeding truck as his two-wheeler lost control after the front wheel hit a stone detached from a nearby pothole. He was run over by the truck and died on the spot. Though the Pettah-Gandhi Square Road is part of the Kochi-Dhanushkodi highway, its condition is pathetic and not properly maintained, said Vishwanathan, a resident near Gandhi-Square. Two weeks ago, a housewife riding her two-wheeler was caught under the wheels of a speeding tipper, while trying to avert a large pothole, in front of NSS Karayogam Hall. “Citing the dilapidated state of this stretch from Pettah to Gandhi Square, we have submitted a memorandum to national highway authorities in December,” said V P Chandran, councillor of the area. However, till date no action had been taken to make the road fit for smooth traffic, he added. Even pedestrians have lost their lives because of the poor condition of the road, said Sivasankaran, a resident of Maradu. Last year, Ravi Menon, a scooter mechanic, was crushed under the wheels of a speeding car, which had lost control while trying to avert a gutter near Tripunithura mini bypass, he said. However, senior officials of National Highways Authority of India insisted that the initial repair works of the stretch between Pettah and Gandhi Square was on and would soon be implemented.
